description: From Latin īcōn, from Ancient Greek εἰκών (eikṓn, “likeness, image, portrait”). Eastern Orthodox Church sense is attested from 1833. Computing sense first recorded in 1982.

entries.meaning: An image, symbol, picture, or other representation usually as an object of religious devotion.
(religion, especially Eastern Christianity) A type of religious painting portraying a saint or scene from Scripture, often done on wooden panels.
(by extension) A person or thing that is the best example of a certain profession or some doing.
examples: That man is an icon in the business; he personifies loyalty and good business sense.

entries.meaning: (graphical user interface) A small picture that represents something.
examples: Click the loudspeaker icon to configure audio settings.

entries.meaning: (linguistics, semiotics) A word, character, or sign whose form reflects and is determined by the referent; onomatopoeic words are necessarily all icons.
